Agency: Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration

Info Source: Taken from the Federal Railroad Administration's FY2001 safety penalty report obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request. A copy is available upon request.

Description: Equistar Chemicals LP, headquartered in Houston, Texas, agreed to pay a civil penalty of $2.5 million and spend more than $125 million on pollution controls and cleanup to address a myriad of air, water and hazardous waste violations at seven petrochemical plants in Texas, Illinois, Iowa and Louisiana.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Notes: Source document obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request to the agency.

Agency: Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration

Description: back pay award in unfair labor practices case
Info Source: Extracted from an NLRB dataset covering 1999-2011 downloaded at https://catalog.data.gov/dataset/nlrb-cats-final-c-case-data-bulk-19990101-20110930-in-xml

Description: The U.S. Department of Labor announced that Lyondell-Citgo Refining LP of Houston would pay 556 current and former employees $391,300 in overtime back pay for violations of the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) overtime requirements. The violations were discovered when the department's Wage and Hour Division found workers were shorted wages from an annual bonus because the employer did not calculate the proper overtime.
Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division

Description: Lyondell and its Chapter 11 creditors agreed to pay $162 million for clean-up expenses at more than a dozen locations.
Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York

Description: Equistar Chemicals agreed to pay a civil penalty of $2.5 million to Iowa, Illinois, Louisiana and the federal government to resolve a variety of air, water and hazardous waste violations at seven petrochemical plants. This was part of a larger $127 million settlement announced by the Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-equistar-chemicals-lp-2

Info Source: Refinery settlement reached; $6.5 million deal involving Lyondell follows state suit, Houston Chronicle, August 26, 2008 (via Nexis).

Notes: Penalty listed includes a $13,000 Supplemental Environmental Project.

Description: A U.S. Department of Labor Occupational Safety and Health Administration whistleblower investigation determined that the dismissal of an account manager by Equistar Chemical, a subsidiary of LyondellBasell, was in retaliation for protected activities under the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.
Lyondell agreed to pay $4 million to settle litigation related to MTBE contamination of the water supply in South Lake Tahoe, California.
Private Litigation Case Title: SO. TAHOE PUBLIC VS. ATLANTIC RICHFIELD

Description: Three U.S. subsidiaries of Dutch chemical giant LyondellBasell Industries N.V. agreed to make upgrades and perform compliance measures estimated to cost $50 million to resolve allegations they violated the Clean Air Act and state air pollution control laws at six petrochemical manufacturing facilities located in Channelview, Corpus Christi, and LaPorte, Texas, and Clinton, Iowa. Lyondell will also pay a $3.4 million civil penalty.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
